title: How to Cure Winter Squash

steps.headline: Harvest mature squash with hard peels that don’t yield to pressure.
steps.description: Gently press a thumbnail into a rind to check for ripeness. A mature squash should resist the pressure. Other signs of ripeness include an opaque, dull rind color and dried, dead stem. Harvest squash before or as soon as the vine and stem die. Damage from the sun, disease, and insects is more likely after the vine dies, and overmature flesh can become dry and stringy. You can still cure a slightly immature squash, but it won’t keep as long or taste as good.

steps.headline: Remove them from the field before temperatures drop below 50 °F (10 °C).
steps.description: Squash are prone to chilling injury, which can lead to rot and shorten their shelf life. From harvest through storage, ensure temperatures remain above 50 °F (10 °C). The curing process can ripen immature fruit, but you might be out of luck if temperatures drop too soon. If squash are too immature, an early frost could destroy 80 to 90 percent of your crop.

steps.headline: Handle squash carefully to prevent injury.
steps.description: Squash seem hardy, but any injury to the peel will cut their storage life. Avoid stacking them on top of each other, throwing them around, or otherwise exposing them to damage. Minor cuts to the surface can heal during the curing process, but bruises will not heal.

steps.headline: Trim the stems to less than 1 inch (2.5 cm).
steps.description: Use clean pruning shears to cut the stems. Stems longer than 1 inch (2.5 cm) can damage nearby squash during storage or transport. Hubbard squash will store better if you cut off the stem completely.

steps.headline: Dip squash in 135 to 140 °F (57 to 60 °C) water for 3 minutes to sterilize them.
steps.description: While you could just brush dirt off after harvesting the crop, a hot water bath will help kill bacteria and deter rot. Dry a squash with a clean cloth immediately after sterilizing it. Some people wash the surface with a solution of 1 part bleach to 10 parts water instead of dipping squash in hot water. Regardless of your method, drying the squash immediately after getting it wet is essential.

steps.headline: Store them in a temperature-controlled greenhouse, shed, or cabinet.
steps.description: A shed or cabinet is fine for 10 or 20 squashes, but larger yields might require a greenhouse or other spacious area. Set up an electric heater with a thermostat to control the temperature and a humidifier or dehumidifier (or both) to control the humidity. Set up a humidity meter in the area you want to cure your squash. If the relative humidity is consistently below 80 percent, you’ll need a humidifier. If it’s usually above 85 percent, you’ll need a dehumidifier. You’ll need both if it fluctuates outside of those margins.

steps.headline: Place the squash on soft material.
steps.description: Store the squash off of the ground on shelving lined with carpeting strips, thick pads of newspaper, or other shock-absorbing material. Place them 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) apart to allow even heat distribution.

steps.headline: Maintain a temperature of 80 to 85 °F (27 to 29 °C).
steps.description: Set the heater’s thermostat to the right temperature and keep a reliable thermometer in the curing location. Check the temperature regularly to make sure it stays in the proper range. It’s not the end of the world if the temperature falls into the 60s or 70s for a few hours. Just bring the temperature up and consider curing them an extra day. The only absolute must is to keep the temperature above 50 °F (10 °C).

steps.headline: Keep the relative humidity between 80 and 85 percent.
steps.description: Check the humidity regularly and adjust your humidifier and dehumidifier as needed. Relative humidity is vital to the process. If it’s too high, condensation will encourage rot. Low humidity will cause dehydration.

steps.headline: Check for spots and discoloration daily.
steps.description: Examine your squash daily during the curing process and throughout their storage. Look for bruises, dark spots, weeping, and other blemishes. Remove a blemished squash immediately to keep the rest of the crop healthy. If spots are small and skin-deep, the flesh is fine to eat. Just use it promptly. If the spots are widespread and the peel is soft and wet, discard the squash.

steps.headline: Cure your squash for 10 to 20 days.
steps.description: During the curing process, sugar content increases, peels harden, and minor cuts heal. When you notice the peels have hardened, transfer the squash to a cool storage location. Curing time isn’t set in stone, so feel the peels daily and gauge their hardness. You can cure squash at a high temperature for up to 3 weeks, but there’s no evidence that curing them longer than 2 weeks improves storage time or taste.

steps.headline: Store squash on soft material in a well-ventilated area.
steps.description: After curing them, move your squash to a garage, shed, or other cool, dry place. Set up an oscillating fan to maintain air circulation. Store them off of the ground on shelving lined with shock-absorbing material. The floor temperature could fall below 50 °F (10 °C), so keep them elevated to prevent chilling injury.

steps.headline: Keep the temperature between 50 and 59 °F (10 and 15 °C).
steps.description: You’ll need to choose a storage spot where the temperature won’t rise above 59 °F (15 °C). If you store the squash in an outdoor shed or garage and live in a cold climate, you might need a thermostat-controlled electric heater. If the temperature spikes, you might need to store the squash in a cooler, preferably one with a thermostat that you can set to the proper temperature.

steps.headline: Maintain a relative humidity of 50 to 70 percent.
steps.description: Place a humidity meter in the storage facility, and check the relative humidity regularly. Depending on your local conditions, use a humidifier, dehumidifier, or both to maintain the right humidity. High humidity will cause condensation and rot, and low humidity will lead to dehydration.

steps.headline: Keep squash away from ripening fruits.
steps.description: Apples, bananas, and other ripening fruits produce ethylene, which causes squash to turn yellow and shortens storage life.

steps.headline: Store squash for at least 2 to 3 months.
steps.description: Even without curing, most squash can be safely stored for months. Discoloration and soft, wet peels are signs that you should throw out a squash. Acorn squash has the shortest shelf life and should not be cured, since it shortens their shelf life. You can keep acorn squash in a cool, dry place for 5 to 8 weeks. Butternut squash can be stored for 2 to 3 months or more. Hubbard squash will keep for up to 6 months.

tyn: Greenhouse, shed, or other curing area
Garage, shed, or other storage area

A mature squash should resist the pressure. Other signs of ripeness include an opaque, dull rind color and dried, dead stem. Harvest squash before or as soon as the vine and stem die. Damage from the sun, disease, and insects is more likely after the vine dies, and overmature flesh can become dry and stringy. You can still cure a slightly immature squash, but it won’t keep as long or taste as good. Remove them from the field before temperatures drop below 50 °F (10 °C). Squash are prone to chilling injury, which can lead to rot and shorten their shelf life. From harvest through storage, ensure temperatures remain above 50 °F (10 °C). The curing process can ripen immature fruit, but you might be out of luck if temperatures drop too soon. If squash are too immature, an early frost could destroy 80 to 90 percent of your crop. Handle squash carefully to prevent injury. Squash seem hardy, but any injury to the peel will cut their storage life. Avoid stacking them on top of each other, throwing them around, or otherwise exposing them to damage. Minor cuts to the surface can heal during the curing process, but bruises will not heal. Trim the stems to less than 1 inch (2.5 cm). Use clean pruning shears to cut the stems. Stems longer than 1 inch (2.5 cm) can damage nearby squash during storage or transport. Hubbard squash will store better if you cut off the stem completely. Dip squash in 135 to 140 °F (57 to 60 °C) water for 3 minutes to sterilize them. While you could just brush dirt off after harvesting the crop, a hot water bath will help kill bacteria and deter rot. Dry a squash with a clean cloth immediately after sterilizing it. Some people wash the surface with a solution of 1 part bleach to 10 parts water instead of dipping squash in hot water. Regardless of your method, drying the squash immediately after getting it wet is essential. Curing the Crop Store them in a temperature-controlled greenhouse, shed, or cabinet. A shed or cabinet is fine for 10 or 20 squashes, but larger yields might require a greenhouse or other spacious area. Set up an electric heater with a thermostat to control the temperature and a humidifier or dehumidifier (or both) to control the humidity. Set up a humidity meter in the area you want to cure your squash. If the relative humidity is consistently below 80 percent, you’ll need a humidifier. If it’s usually above 85 percent, you’ll need a dehumidifier. You’ll need both if it fluctuates outside of those margins. Place the squash on soft material. Store the squash off of the ground on shelving lined with carpeting strips, thick pads of newspaper, or other shock-absorbing material. Place them 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) apart to allow even heat distribution. Maintain a temperature of 80 to 85 °F (27 to 29 °C). Set the heater’s thermostat to the right temperature and keep a reliable thermometer in the curing location. Check the temperature regularly to make sure it stays in the proper range. It’s not the end of the world if the temperature falls into the 60s or 70s for a few hours. Just bring the temperature up and consider curing them an extra day. The only absolute must is to keep the temperature above 50 °F (10 °C). Keep the relative humidity between 80 and 85 percent. Check the humidity regularly and adjust your humidifier and dehumidifier as needed. Relative humidity is vital to the process. If it’s too high, condensation will encourage rot. Low humidity will cause dehydration. Check for spots and discoloration daily. Examine your squash daily during the curing process and throughout their storage. Look for bruises, dark spots, weeping, and other blemishes. Remove a blemished squash immediately to keep the rest of the crop healthy. If spots are small and skin-deep, the flesh is fine to eat. Just use it promptly. If the spots are widespread and the peel is soft and wet, discard the squash. Cure your squash for 10 to 20 days. During the curing process, sugar content increases, peels harden, and minor cuts heal. When you notice the peels have hardened, transfer the squash to a cool storage location. Curing time isn’t set in stone, so feel the peels daily and gauge their hardness. You can cure squash at a high temperature for up to 3 weeks, but there’s no evidence that curing them longer than 2 weeks improves storage time or taste. Storing Cured Winter Squash Store squash on soft material in a well-ventilated area. After curing them, move your squash to a garage, shed, or other cool, dry place. Set up an oscillating fan to maintain air circulation. Store them off of the ground on shelving lined with shock-absorbing material. The floor temperature could fall below 50 °F (10 °C), so keep them elevated to prevent chilling injury. Keep the temperature between 50 and 59 °F (10 and 15 °C). You’ll need to choose a storage spot where the temperature won’t rise above 59 °F (15 °C). If you store the squash in an outdoor shed or garage and live in a cold climate, you might need a thermostat-controlled electric heater. If the temperature spikes, you might need to store the squash in a cooler, preferably one with a thermostat that you can set to the proper temperature. Maintain a relative humidity of 50 to 70 percent. Place a humidity meter in the storage facility, and check the relative humidity regularly. Depending on your local conditions, use a humidifier, dehumidifier, or both to maintain the right humidity. High humidity will cause condensation and rot, and low humidity will lead to dehydration. Keep squash away from ripening fruits. Apples, bananas, and other ripening fruits produce ethylene, which causes squash to turn yellow and shortens storage life. Store squash for at least 2 to 3 months. Even without curing, most squash can be safely stored for months. Discoloration and soft, wet peels are signs that you should throw out a squash. Acorn squash has the shortest shelf life and should not be cured, since it shortens their shelf life. You can keep acorn squash in a cool, dry place for 5 to 8 weeks. Butternut squash can be stored for 2 to 3 months or more. Hubbard squash will keep for up to 6 months.
